resources.string: Within ES File Explorer files are found in /Pictures
ES File Explorer (available from the Google Play Store free!) is recommended for viewing photos and results from this application.
1. Calibrating BACTICOUNT to count bacterial DNA in a blood sample. You\'ll need known concentrations of genomic DNA samples arranged like so on a hotplate:
2. Place hotplate under a sealed box with radial UV LED\'s attached to the top and a viewfinder-sized hole for this camera.
3. Construct box with dimensions that allow viewfinder to perfectly align with vials on hotplate.

4. Attach blue-blocking lens filter to this camera, put phone on box, and prepare tape to secure phone during recording. Proceed to "Start" from the home screen, then "record standard curve". Follow the instructions until the 70-minute recording is complete.
Aiite. Don\'t bore me to death :P

5. Now that you\'ve successfully recorded a calibration standard curve, complete the same procedure for a set of unknown live blood samples (still use a [+] and [-] control) by going to "record sample" from "start" on the home screen. After this 70 minute recording is complete, you\'re ready to analyze the results! \n \n 6. Using BACTICOUNT to count bacteria in a blood sample. From "start" go to "select and view results". Here you\'ll be prompted to choose both a calibration (.pasc) and set of unknowns for analysis (.pasc). Simply select one from the prompted folders of the run names you recorded earlier, and hit "proceed". Results will be displayed, in powers of 10 for each of the 8 unknown vials alongside checks for [+] and [-] controls (required to pass for calibrations and unknown samples). They are exported to the same folder (*_analysis.txt) for viewing or verification, along with raw data from all recordings.

7. Much more detailed instructions can be found at [link to BACTICOUNT.com- available! we should register it]. Note: installation of "Open CV manager" will be prompted during the process. Play Store access is required to install, necessary for proper BACTICOUNT operation (You will leave and re-enter BACTICOUNT). Here is a list of needed supplies

Reagents 
-Blood lysis: alkaline reagent (NaOH, Triton X-100) 
-Tris-HCl (pH 7.5) 

Amplification:
-positive control containing target gene (genomic DNA)
-primers (F3, B3, FIP, BIP, with optional addition of F Loop and B Loop)
-2x reagent mix (Bst DNA polymerase, Tris-HCl, KCl, MgSO4, (NH4)2SO4, Tween-20, Triton X-100, betaine, dNTPs, FDR)
-PCR-clean H2O

Materials
-sterilized tubes
-aluminum 96-well tube holder
-smartphone with app
-520 nm optical filter
-tape
-low-profile strip PCR tubes
-optical flat strip PCR lids
-micropipette
-pipette tips with filter
-vortex mixer
-centrifuge
-ice
-heat block
-blue LED lights
-battery
-blackout box with viewing aperture
-Moto X 2nd Gen in airplane mode

Predetermined Parameters
-primers for target gene
-concentration of positive control
-temperature for amplification

string.name: recording_reaction_text_view_recording_now
string.b: NOW RECORDING. Do not move device, tap any buttons, unplug power, or respond to notifications.

resources.string: Snapping 1 photo every 10 seconds for 50 minutes, 300 photos total.
This will not actually be displayed

Aim camera directly at reaction vials and line up to grid as carefully as possible. Place camera in stable position on box and hit record. Ensure that the camera WILL NOT MOVE during recording. Before recording begins, as a precaution it is required that the user close all other applications that utilize the camera (Snapchat, Stock Camera, Instagram, etc) else results cannot be guaranteed. The device must be left in an undisturbed state during recording, and it is recommended that auto-updates, notifications, and all other active or interrupting activities be disabled. Putting the device into airplane mode is one such option.
This is the exact grid the vials will need to be aligned to
Merely a sample of what the viewfinder will actually look like

The positive (+) and negative (-) indicate success of a sample if both are marked YES. Bottom 2 rows show the initial concentration, in powers of 10 of the bacterial concentration. For example, if one shows 3.14, this indicates there is 1 x 10^3.14 bacteria per milliliter in that vial sample.
This is what the results might look like
Please select an action. You may record a standard curve, record a sample for analysis, or view results.
AS OF RIGHT NOW, ONLY THE "RECORD STANDARD CURVE"; BUTTON WORKS. That and the back button…
Enter a name of this standard curve for recording. Only the characters Aa–Zz, 0–9, and the underscore symbol (_) are allowed, no periods (.), special characters, or spaces please!
Enter a name of this sample for recording. Only the characters Aa–Zz, 0–9, and the underscore symbol (_) are allowed, no periods (.), special characters, or spaces please!
This field is for testing and debugging

Please select a valid ".pasc" calibration file and a sample to test it against. Such files are located in the "Pictures" directory in their corresponding folder, then tap "proceed" to set up your recording.

300 photos were taken over 50 minutes. From the home screen, select "Start", then "Select and view results" to complete the BACTICOUNT analysis. You may compare any set of unknown samples with a standard curve calibration run. The home screen has instructions for viewing or exporting all 300 photos.
